did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.abstract: The collection consists of Bonelli's letters, documents, photographs, programs, publications, scores, scrapbooks, audiovisual materials, posters and newspaper clippings.
did.langmaterial: Languages represented in the collection: English

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research. Listening appointments may require 24 hours notice. Contact the Archive Operations Manager.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: Property rights reside with repository. Publication and reproduction rights reside with the creators or their heirs. To obtain permission to publish or reproduce, please contact the Head Librarian of the Archive of Recorded Sound.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Richard Bonelli Collection, ARS-0005. Courtesy of the Stanford Archive of Recorded Sound, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

bioghist.head: Biography / Administrative History
bioghist.p: Baritone Richard Bonelli was born Richard Bunn in Port Byron, New York on Feb. 2, 1889. His voice teachers were Arthur Alexander in Los Angeles, and Jean de Reszke and William Valonat in Paris. His operatic debut was as Valentin in Gounod's Faust at the Brooklyn Academy in 1915. From 1922-24 he toured the U.S. with the San Carlo opera company. After touring in Europe with the Max Sauter Company in 1925, he was engaged at the Theatre Gaite Lyrique in Paris. That same year he was to join the Chicago Opera Company, remaining there until 1931. Between 1926 and 1942 he was a frequent guest at the San Francisco Opera, and was also a member of the Metropolitan Opera from 1932-45. After retiring from the stage he dedicated himself to voice pedagogy and was a much-appreciated teacher. He taught at the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia, and at the Music Academy of the West. Richard Bonelli died in Los Angeles on June 7, 1980.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The collection includes several hundred personal and business letters; documents ranging from private matters, such as his divorce papers from his first wife Pauline Curley, to professional matters, such as his multiple opera contracts; photographs from his childhood and family, a large number of promotional portrait photographs, some featuring him in costume for various opera roles; a collection of programs; publications, mainly dealing with opera companies; annotated opera vocal scores and songs; seven scrapbooks containing mainly newspaper clippings; audiovisual materials; testimonials; and posters and newspaper clippings.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series 1. Correspondence. 2. Documents. 3. Photographs. 4. Programs. 5. Publications. 6. Scores. 7. Scrapbooks. 8. Publications. 9. Films. 10. Sound recordings. 11. Testimonials and awards. 12. Posters and snakes. 13. News clippings. 14. Miscellany.

controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the library's online public access catalog.

Black and white, silent movie with the following titles: Rehearsal for Muzio, Meisle, Pinza, Gandolfi and Bonelli ; Aida. Finale of triumphal scene. Muzio, Meisle, Martinelli and Bonelli ; Tristan und Isolde. Bonelli as Kurneval and Pinza as king Mark ; Entr' acte callers. Augusta and Ned Harrold, Merle Preston and Dale Winter Duffy ; La Boheme. Bori, Bonelli, Hardi and Borgioli ; Forza del Destino. Muzio, Bonelli, Martinelli, Pinza and Gandolfi ; Coq d'or. Bolm as the king and Ruiz as the princess ; Tannhäuser rehearsal. The minstrel's contest in the hall of song ; Tannhäuser Act II. Dress rehearsal for the chorus. Bonelli as Wolfram, Pinza as the Landgraf Gandolfi and Windheim ; La Traviata. Act III, ballroom at Flora's ; Lauritz Melchior and Bonelli stage an impromptu rehearsal of Otello; Aida. Martinelli as Rhadames, Coe Glade as Amneris, Bonelli as Amonasro, Rothberg as Aida ; Entr' ácte. Agnini, Bonelli, Robert Miller and Windheim ; Dress rehearsal with Helen Gahagan as Suor Angelica ; Rigoletto. Bonelli as Rigoletto, Schipa as the duke, Emily Hardy as Gilda ; Manon. Nov. 10th. with Bovy, Maison, Bonelli, Cordon and Cehanovsky ; Our supper party, Nov. 17th ; La Forza del Destino. Rethberg, Gigli, Bonelli.
